messages.content: My mobile wallet MVP was generated using JHipster and is in a github repository.  I want to regenerate a second version of the application but in the same repository.  how can i avoid breaking the first application and not overwirting the same files?  I want to keep them both to allow me to gradually move functionality from the first application to the second one.

One solution could be to use branches in your repository to keep your two versions separate. You can create a new branch for the second version and make changes to that branch without affecting the first version. You can merge the changes from the new branch back into the main branch when you're ready to merge them into the first application. This will allow you to keep both versions of the application in the same repository and gradually move functionality from the first application to the second one.
I rely on continuous integration and prefere to have a single branch.  also, i would be deploying both applciations.  i will not be able to change the first applications source tree to add "v1".

In that case, you can use tags in your repository to differentiate between your two versions. Create a new tag for the second version and update the application to use that tag in its manifest. You can then create a separate branch for the second version, make changes to that branch, and then merge the changes back into the main branch. This will keep both versions of the application in the same repository and allow you to gradually move functionality from the first application to the second one. When you're ready to deploy, you can use the appropriate tags to deploy the correct version of the application.
can i do this using gradle?  and since i deploy as docker containers i would generate two different containers.

Yes, you can use Gradle to achieve this. You can define two different build.gradle files - one for the first version of the application and one for the second version. In the build.gradle file for each version, you can specify the appropriate tags and use the appropriate Docker images to generate the two different containers. This will keep both versions of the application in the same repository and allow you to gradually move functionality from the first application to the second one. When you're ready to deploy, you can use the appropriate tags to deploy the correct version of the application, and the appropriate Docker images to generate the two different containers.
is this simpler than generating a separate and independent application in a new repository?

It may be more complex than generating a separate and independent application in a new repository, but it does have some advantages. It allows you to keep both versions of the application in the same repository and allows you to gradually move functionality from the first application to the second one. It also allows you to use tags and branches to differentiate between the two versions and make it easier to deploy the correct version. However, if simplicity is your main concern, you may want to consider generating a separate and independent application in a new repository.
